page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
H. to understand, that sins
e deliverie of my former letters to this bearer
who hath had no meanes to depart, by reason of
e
frost, I have dealt w
t
e
Generall states
in the
affaires of
Ostend,
and have advertised my
LL.
of their Answear: wherof I send yo
r
H.
e copie,
and of mine owne Proposition, and Replie, whiche,
if yo
r
H. see requisit, I beseeche yo
w
deliver.
There was a motion made of late by
Count Maurice
,
that there might be some fortification in
e litle Ile
of
Biervliet,
adjoining to
Walcheren,
where it is
found by triall that
e water there, uppon
e coast
of
Flanders,
beareth 14 foote depth, and may serve
to harbour 200 shippes of great burden: whiche
would be a fitte retrait for an other Spanishe fleete,
and also otherwise a c
o
modious haven for many
of
e Enemies purposes in these contreis. For at
Hendoncke
and other fronter places on Flanders side
there may be artillerie planted, and sufficient
blockhouses made for
e safegard of their shippes.
There hath bin good conference heere uppon it,
and it is thought a very necessary worke, but
at
they are troubled who should beare
e charge.
Howbeit I thinke in
e end, it will falle uppon
Zeland to disbourse
e mony, to be deducted
afterwardes uppon their extraordinarie contribu-
tions. The
states of Utrecht
, as I
signified in part, in my last to yo
r
H. have
discharged 4 of their ministers, whiche was all
ei
had in
e towne, and take in others for them.
And thus I take my humble leave. From
e
Hage. Dec
r
26. 89
Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley.
